awd_titl_txt: FET: Medium: Collaborative Research: Engineerable Molecular Computing: Flying like an Airplane, not like a Bird
awd_abstract_narration:
Computation via chemical reactions is prevalent in biology as every cell performs sophisticated information processing on internal and external chemical signals. Engineering synthetic biochemical pathways that are likewise capable of decision-making will impact a range of applications in manufacturing, chemical sensing, and medicine. Work funded by this project constructs smart molecular systems using two novel paradigms that, although inspired by biology, are very different from evolved biological systems (analogously to how airplanes do not fly by flapping their wings). The success of this project will lead to a new understanding of how chemical reactions can perform information processing, and to a new generation of functional molecular devices. The educational and outreach activities funded by this project, in collaboration with the Association for Women in Mathematics, also address the serious problem of the low percentage of women in computer science research.

Direct analysis and manipulation of molecular information (e.g., the information encoded in the concentrations of various molecules) is where molecular computing outcompetes its electronic counterparts. The project advances the computer science theory and experimental capability to engineer chemical information processing with nucleic acids (DNA) by two new paradigms: (1) molecular computation programmed by the stoichiometry of reactions (independent of reaction rates); (2) molecular computation programmed by a simple combinatorial model of thermodynamics. The new paradigms result in greater robustness and easier programmability than existing approaches. Also, in contrast to existing methods, this proposal will yield reusable molecular computation, whereby switching the input results in dynamically updating output.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
**Intellectual Merit:** 
The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in developing new systematic ways of programming smart molecular systems. For the existing technology of DNA strand displacement cascades, new methods of programming computation using reaction stoichiometry were theoretically analyzed and experimentally implemented. Going beyond strand displacement cascades, behavior was systematically programmed by the design of thermodynamic equilibria rather than the kinetic pathway, and DNA systems were engineered such that fast kinetic pathways automatically exist. Importantly, in contrast with existing methods, this proposal resulted in reusable molecular computation, where switching the input results in dynamically updating output.
Significant work was accomplished in both thrusts of the proposal (1) Stoichiometric analog computation with chemical reactions, and (2) Molecular algorithms programmed by thermodynamic binding networks. Several conjectures from each aim were proven, which were disseminated to the broader research community in peer-reviewed conference and journal publications. In addition, some experimental results were obtained in each thrust, which the PIs are currently preparing for submission to journals.


**Broader Impacts:** The proposal's approach treats chemical systems as information-rich and programmable, thus requiring an approach founded on the information sciences. The proposed research brought the fields of chemistry, biology, and computer science closer to each other intellectually. For example, understanding how efficient information processing is possible in the insufficiently ordered world of chemistry generalizes to electronic computing in settings lacking the defined memory space and synchrony of the von Neumann architecture (i.e., the domain of distributed computing). The exciting applications of smart molecular systems in medicine exemplify the direct way in which molecular algorithms in the models studied here could benefit society (molecular algorithms for identifying and curing diseases.)


The project also contributed to the development of undergraduate and graduate courses, which will train students in applying the principles of computer science and electrical engineering to traditionally incompatible domains. The PI participated in the AvenueE and VIP research programs at UC Davis as part of the project, programs respectively for helping community college transfer students to be mentored by faculty and getting involved in research.


Last Modified: 07/04/2023
Modified by: David S Doty
